TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi sealed beforefieldinit DependentHandle extends System.ValueType implements class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Represents a dependent garbage-collection handle. The handle will conditionally keep a dependent object instance alive as long as a target object instance is alive as well, without representing a strong reference to the target instance.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
A <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle> value with a given object instance as target will not cause the target to be kept alive if there are no other strong references to it, but it will do so for the dependent object instance as long as the target is alive.
Using this type is conceptually equivalent to having a weak reference to a given target object instance A, with that object having a field or property (or some other strong reference) to a dependent object instance B.
The <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle> type is not thread-safe, and consumers are responsible for ensuring that <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dispose> is not called concurrently with other APIs. Not doing so results in undefined behavior.
The <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.IsAllocated>, <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Target>, <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dependent>, and <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.TargetAndDependent> properties are instead thread-safe, and safe to use if <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dispose> is not concurrently invoked as well.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(object target, object dependent) cil managed
Public Sub New (target As Object, dependent As Object)

Docs.param: The target object instance to track.
The dependent object instance to associate with .
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct with the specified arguments.

MemberSignature.Value: member this.Dependent : obj with get, set
public: property System::Object ^ Dependent { System::Object ^ get(); void set(System::Object ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the dependent object instance for the current handle.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
If you need to retrieve both <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Target> and <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dependent>, ensure that the returned instance from <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Target> will be kept alive until <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dependent> is retrieved as well, or it might be collected and result in unexpected behavior. This can be done by storing the target in a local and calling <xref:System.GC.KeepAlive(System.Object)> on it after <xref:System.Runtime.DependentHandle.Dependent> is accessed.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Dispose() cil managed
abstract member Dispose : unit -> unit override this.Dispose : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Performs application-defined tasks associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
This method is not thread-safe.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsAllocated As Boolean
public: property bool IsAllocated { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance was constructed with and has not yet been disposed.
Docs.value: if this instance was constructed with and has not yet been disposed; otherwise.

MemberSignature.Value: member this.Target : obj with get, set
public: property System::Object ^ Target { System::Object ^ get(); void set(System::Object ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the target object instance for the current handle. The target can only be set to a value once the instance has been created. Doing so will cause to start returning as well, and to become eligible for collection even if the previous target is still alive.
Docs.value: The target object instance for the current handle.
Docs.exception: is or the input value is not .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property TargetAndDependent As ValueTuple(Of Object, Object)
public: property ValueTuple<System::Object ^, System::Object ^> TargetAndDependent { ValueTuple<System::Object ^, System::Object ^> get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the values of both and (if available) as an atomic operation. That is, even if is concurrently set to , calling this method will either return for both target and dependent, or return both previous values. If and were used sequentially in this scenario instead, it would be possible to sometimes successfully retrieve the previous target, but then fail to get the dependent.
